What do you print for someone who has everything, as in every smartphone, table and wearable? One place where they can keep and charge all of them, no matter how many there are! Included is a front piece and a modular, repeatable back piece. Each part can hold up to 3 devices. The honeycomb array is as strong as it is nifty. Vines of it being printed:
https://vine.co/v/MTlVQHvH9wI
https://vine.co/v/Mt7qTeZ0JTI

The prints should be scaled to fit ~1cm wide devices in them.
The included files should be ready to print on their edges, 7 cm wide each. The _2 files have all beveled sides, which may not make for easy printing. The _3 files (shown in the picture) have flattened sides and printed very easily.
Printed with an Ultimaker with 0.8mm sides and 10% fill. The white printed at 100 mm/s, 210 degrees C, and the blue at 70 mm/s, 220 degrees C.

title: Kossel Mini Top Filament spool with 3.5 hardrive bearing

description.text:
This is a simple filament spool plate and mounting bracket for the Kossel mini delta printer. It use an old hardrive bearing and m3 screw and nuts however they are not required as gravity and spool weight keep in place without screws.
Thx to TheDigitalAlchemist question not everyone left nuts on the inside of the beam.
Edit: Plate Mount v1 and v2 should allow you to mount the spool from the top of the frame instead of the inside of the beam.
Both of these have not been tested but should work please without problem let me know if something not right will try to amend it
Large print almost using the whole bed of the Kossel make sure you slow down your first layers to reduce the chance of warping.

comments.text: I built this and mounted it on my Delta Mini.  It looks awesome!!!
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: Is there a simple way to make it not want to unwind every chance it gets.
comments.author: flux83

comments.text: You could print a simple filament guide that screw to the top frame allowing the filament to pass through in it's way to the extruder. However I didn't had much problem with filament unwind on mine when the filament is loaded the reel usually unwind slowly in same time the filament is extruded.
comments.author: flux83

comments.text: I like your thinking. I've got a 5.5L cake storage box that I was thinking of sitting on top of the Kossel mini, with a turntable like contraption allowing the spool to spin inside. I'll have a PTFE tube take the filament from box to the extruder, the idea being to keep it as moisture free as possible. The weather in the UK is very variable and I think moisture got to my previous batch, one day it was printing, the next the head was just pushing around a growing blob.
comments.author: MARKSE

comments.text:
For the contraption look at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:117949 and you just need to drop the open hardrive in your box with a spool adaptor. If you worried about damp I use those moisture drying pack inside of the cake box or put silicate packet in there
http://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00E4L3VL6/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
comments.author: MARKSE

comments.text: This loks great until you take apart an old hard drive and discover you need to CUT THE CASE TO KEEP THE BEARING. in th first picture I can see it now that I have take one apart. Maybe you should have explained that part?
comments.author: bigdaddio

comments.text: I used a hammer to knock out the bearings from the bottom of the hard drive.
comments.author: bigdaddio

comments.text: Woah you had to cut yours out. Mine was able to be popped out using the back of a hatchet(couldn't find my hammer) and a screwdriver.

comments.text: Assume responsibility for your action. This is not http://instructables.cominstructables.com I don't have to explain anything related to extraction of the part required maybe http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:117949http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... is more suited for you. STOP SHOUTING OUT AT PEOPLE MAYBE YOU SHOULD THINK OF THAT?
comments.author: bigdaddio

comments.text:
Hi your design is exactly what I have been looking for for my MK. I have spools with different sized center holes, do you envision using adapter plates for the different sized spools?
What is the purpose of the two different top mounts?
comments.author: thanatos

comments.text: Yes I have 3 spool adaptor that I've made at the moment will upload them soon! The purpose of the different mount is simple, as you can see on the picture I use the mount that fit inside the triangle and plate rest slightly below I could do this because I've left some nuts in the beam. Someone enquired about this as he didn't had left nuts in there than I've made the other one for him :-)

Left and right hemispheres of human brain.
Subject is male, 35 years and, hopefully, without pathological deformities.
Endless possibilities of meshing.
Just put your ... mind to it.
I printet this model on a Makerbot 2x, using red ABS wich I sprayed with acetone-vapor in the cleaning process.

comments.author: willowmountford

comments.text:
Hi willowmountford!
Yeah, its segmentet from a MRI-scan, so its 100% correct.
Naturally, since the cerebellum is removed, there are some small fragments of overlapping structures, but it`s all brain :)

comments.text: i mostly make brackets so i did a low res print.  it took 6 hours per hemisphere with 0.8mm nozzle at 0.4mm layers, but it came out great.  It is a little rough in some spots, but overall great for a working model.

comments.text: I´m glad to hear, Simonpackman1! Theres some delicate structures on this model and Ive never seen it printed in 0.8 and 0.4 :)

I've printed this in Makerbot myself, and the scale should remain 1:1 when imported into MakerWare.
Happy printing! :)

I'm pulling down Freesurfer now (nifty app BTW!). Did it allow you to export to STL natively or did you have to do any any tricks to get STL output? I've checked out the wiki and don't see anything obvious (yet).
Just curious are you in the medical field? I'll be attending RSNA in Chicago next month specifically for the 3D printing track.
comments.author: MiloMi

comments.text: can i make him smarter?
comments.author: Testler

comments.text: Im open to suggestions :)
comments.author: Testler

comments.text: I went to slice this at 100 microns.  I heard a snail went around the world 8 times before I saw a progress bar.  So my advice to everyone...  PRINT AT LOW RESOLUTION.  Make it look pretty in post.  Awesome model though.  I am printing it in gold, so I can carry it around at work to win arguments.  Who is right, my manager?  Or the man with a golden brain in his backpack?  I need to put a chain on it and wear it as a necklace.
comments.author: gallowraven

comments.text:
Startet slicing it at 100 microns myself, wich pretty much caused my computer to shout "Attica" and start a major riot.
Low res is a GOOD advice :)
I painted a right hempisphere in a dark brownish colour, just for the heck of it.
It only makes me hum "Chocolate Brain" every time I see it.
comments.author: gallowraven

comments.text: I printed them "as is", temporal lobe pointing down and with raft + support. Basically you are going to end up with a lot of support wich ever way you print it, due to the structure, but let me know if you try and succeed with any other orientation :)

title: Mendel Mini extruder Mount for Kossel Mini

description.text:
I've made a better one! Have a look http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:380682
This came to life after my pneumatic push fit connector failed on the friday night at 11pm. I just couldn't stop printing and designed that simple extruder mount bracket.
One of them will allow you to have the pneumatic push fit connector threaded onto your extruder body and the other allow you to put an m4 nuts on the ptfe tube and constrict it against the extruder body.
The push fit connector version is a mixin of "Mendel Mini extruder mount for the Kossel Mini" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:177029
standard print with 0.2 layer, 3 shells and 25% infill

The original ceiling blade bracket broke, but instead of buying one of equally poor resistance, I made a new one out of ABS. The 3D printed part is actually stronger than the metal one. How do I know that? I loaded another metal bracket of the same fan until it broke. Then I did the same thing to the plastic one, but it did not break under the same load. I ended making 2 brackets, but I now have the confidence it won't break in use.

This part must be printed with supports, with the motor mount holes side up (~170° to what the preview shows). I printed it with 65% infill and it holds up nicely under load.  
Print and use at YOUR own risk. I have not done any exhaustive testing to see how long it will last under normal ceiling fan use. Proceed with caution. The blade mounting holes are NOT tapped. You will have to do that manually after it's printed.  
For an increased safety factor, use longer screws and a nut, instead of relying on the plastic thread alone.  
I included a simple drawing in the pictures showing its dimensions. Those are given in millimeters, if it was not obvious. Though it says "Scale 1:1", I have no idea if printing it would scale it differently.
EDIT (19/Sep/2017): The 1st bracket that was put in service finally failed after a little over 3 years of service. I'll reinforce the area that failed and repost the new version as soon as it's ready.

comments.text: Well, it finally happened. The bracket finally broke after about 3 years in service. I think it failed just because of material fatigue. I'll replace this design with a reinforced version, as soon as I have some time to redesign it and print it again.

comments.text:
It's been in "service" for just a few weeks, and it has not shown any signs of creeping (slow bending due to heat and load). Summer is just kicking in, so we'll see if that happens.
As I commented briefly in the instructions, I did try bending it to see if it would fail. I ended up breaking another metal bracket to see when it would fail. I didn't actually measure the force, but I added the same load (several books) and it did not break. What I did see was a slight "whitening" where the stress concentrated. To see what I mean, you can bend a new filament. You will see that it changes color slightly; it gets whiter where it bends. I stopped loading it when that happened, but it was well beyond the load the made the metal one fail. It did not deform it and it's in operation unaffected.
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text: [Update] The printed bracket is still in operation with no traces of deformation or any signs of possible failure. Will update again in another 6 months.

title: PSU panel for custom benchtop powersupply

description.text: Custom built PSU panel that fits standard ATX PSU. 6 banana plug sockets, power-on LED and on-off switch.

• Print the panel
  • Drill a hole on top of the PSU
  • Cut and insulate all unneeded PSU cables. Keep 4 GND (black), 1 Green (PSU-ON), 1 3.3V (orange), 1 5V (red), 1 12V (yellow)
  • Place banana plug sockets in place and wire them with 3.3, 5, 12V and GND
  • Solder a LED with1K? (may vary for different LEDs) in parallel to 3.3V and GND
  • Solder the Switch with Green (poweron) and GND
  • Bolt or stick with double tape your panel on top of the PSU

title: Bengal disc brakes pulley sealing plug for KMX trike

description.text: One of a bunch of improvements I made for my KMX Cobra recumbent trike: Since several of the pulley openings point upwards, they collect dirt and water, eventually leading to corrosion of the pulleys or just freezing in the winter. This thing is intended to seal the end at the brakes a bit better.

print, maybe drill out the hole, squish into brake pulley hole as shown in the picture, then feed the pulley through. Maybe press some grease into thespace under the plug for some extra water resistance.
The hole is significantly bigger in the design than is neccessary for the normal pulley diameter, but my printer tends to shrink small holes, so it fits perfectly for me. Openscad source provided, so change as you like.

This assembly brings a lot of improvements to the original i3 XZ axis system. It is available in two versions, with mounting points for M6 delrin nuts or holes for M5 nuts. Precision leadscrews and delrin nuts are available in eBay.
Changes to original:
  • Mount points for precision delrin nuts
  • Z bearing tightening with screws
  • Better tolerance for 8 mm linear rods
  • Mount point for Z adjuster screw
  • Adjustable belt tightener
  • Belt forces carried by X rods, not Z rods
    • 4.6.2015: added axis ends that have looser tolerance for 8 mm smooth rod
If you want to use the Z axis adjust feature, download endstop holder from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:149882

title: KMX trike brake pulley sealing plug - Handlebar end

description.text: On the KMX trike all brake pulley openings point upwards at the handles and are very effective at collecting and funneling water and dirt into the pulley cables. This thing should fix that at the handlebar end at the price of making pulley removal somewhat more difficult.

Sorry, no pictures, it's impossible to see when already installed. the idea is that you insert this inside the aluminium adjustment screws at the handlebar end. title: MakerGear M2 Printer Spool Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a New design spool holder for the MakerGear M2 Printer. Less stress on filament and x-axis.

Project documentation is dowloadable as a pdf. Project can be made using only items shipped with your m2 3d printer. PLA was used for my prototypes and it works just fine. All Models should be ready for slicing in the correct orientation. A g-code file is included for printing the six required parts on a M2 Printer. It will print the set in under 3 1/2 hours. It is recomended that you use 1/2" schedule 40 PVC pipe for your uprights and crossbar. You can get a 4 foot long piece for $1.25 at a home improvement store. If it is not available then you can use the supplied optional-tube.STL to print them. Print settings used

comments.text:
This works great with the cheap spools unsed by various vendors; the hole in the top of our cold end's ABS was being eroded by the
tension with these cheap spools using the original MakerGear holder, and that doesn't seem to be an issue
with this holder. However, some spools (e.g., from MatterHacker) have too small a center hole. I found that a 3/4" dowel just barely fit through the spool and designed end caps with an internal structure to firmly hold the dowel ends so it doesn't walk out -- http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:257149http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... . Incidentally, I think the MakerGear spools still work better on the original holder, and you can have both mounted simultaneously using the split mounting brackets you have in this design.

Invited to explore physical education with a 3D printer, MakerBot's Design Studio engineered a fun—and functional—solution! With the MakerBot Jump Rope, you can now download and 3D print your very own fitness tool! Infill
Chain Link Clip - 100%
Chain - 100% (print horizontal)
Handle - 2%

Title Jump Rope Math
Subject Physical Education; Applied Math
Grades K-8
Class periods 8-10
Lesson Overview Learn math; increase cardiovascular fitness
Materials Jump ropes

National Standards
Standard 1 - Demonstrates competency in motor skills and movement patterns needed to perform a variety of physical activities.
Standard 2 - Demonstrates understanding of movement concepts, principles, strategies, and tactics as they apply to the learning and performance of physical activities.
Standard 3 - Participates regularly in physical activity.
Standard 4 - Achieves and maintains a health enhancing level of physical fitness.
Standard 5 - Exhibits responsible personal and social behavior that respects self and others in physical activity settings.
Standard 6 - Values physical activity for health, enjoyment, challenge, self-expression, and social interaction.

Lesson Objectives
1. Students will demonstrate knowledge and skills they need to maintain or increase endurance levels throughout unit.
2. Students will perform physical movement skills in a variety of settings.
3. Students will gain an understanding of a variety of jumping skills through guided practice.
4. Students will demonstrate knowledge of sequence and routine (continuous).
5. Students will be able to interact socially with others and remain on task.
6. Students will be able to follow basic skill as modeled by instructor and proceed through guided practice.

Daily Lesson Plans
Day 1: Watch jump rope video with several skills displayed (you tube, teacher tube, jump rope for heart). Explain purpose for daily skills and warm-up. Daily warm-up 60 sec continuous jump. Basic jump skills: Single bounce, skier, bell, and jogger. Teacher demonstrates ----Student performs skill for two minutes after each demonstration. End day with game: who can jump the longest without stopping or mistakes.
Day 2: Warm –up, 60 sec. Continuous jump. Review previous day skills. Teach new skills: side straddle, front straddle (scissors) straddle cross and twist.
End with jump rope relay race.
Day 3: Warm-up, 60 sec. Continuous jump. Review previous day skills. Small routine, practice three skills on a 4 beat routine. Teach new skills: Criss Cross, continuous criss cross, and toe-to-toe. End with challenge skill: double under.
Day 4: Warm-up, 60 sec. Continuous jump. Review previous day skills (student demo). Teach new skills: heal-to-heal, side swing, combination straddle, and forward 180.
End with challenge skill: backward 180.
Day 5: Warm-up, 60 sec. Continuous jump (majority should be jumping the entire time now). Review previous day skills (student demo). Set up jumping stations. 2-3 students per group and rotate. Teacher can assess and give feedback.
Day 6: Warm-up, 80 sec. Continuous jump. Review previous day skills (student demo). Small routine, 4 skills-8 beat count. Teach new skills backward 180 and kick swing.
Day 7: Warm-up, 80 sec. Continuous jump. Review previous day skills (student demo). Teach advance skills: can cans, 360 turn, wounded duck and double under. Explain routine procedures and hand out routine sheets.
Day 8-10: Students should be working on and presenting routines. Teacher can assess during the routines or as they are independently working.

Assessment
Jump rope rubrics, monitoring notes, visual observation, verbal feedback, and modeling for students.

title: Customizable Flex Joint Mold
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Printable mold for flex joints of customizable size, including those for Gyrobot's Flexy-Hand. We are currently experimenting with Smooth-On's "Dragon Skin" silicone but other materials may also be viable. Up-to-date material information for these joints can be found at https://github.com/daprice/Flexy-Joint/wiki/Materials (If you're testing any other materials, your contributions are welcome!) Unlike Gyrobot's Hinge Mould, this is one piece to minimize cleanup after casting, and the open ends can be sealed with tape. The silicone we've tested doesn't stick too much to PLA so the finished pieces can be pushed and/or pulled out easily.
• Update 6/24/14: Each size in the mold is labeled. You can also provide a text label for the whole mold.
This currently doesn't work correctly in Makerbot Customizer for unknown reasons. Try contacting Makerbot support if you need this and can't/don't want to install OpenSCAD on your computer.
See https://github.com/daprice/Flexy-Joint/wiki/Casting

comments.text: So this allows you to print flexy-hands (various models) with no flexible filament?

comments.text: Yes, but keep in mind that I have yet to find a moldable silicone/rubber (that can be cast at room temperature using a 3D printed mold) that lasts as long as printed Filaflex does.

title: NEMA 23 Adaptations for Cherry Pi III Printer

description.text:
These are three modified parts that I will be attempting to use to fit NEMA 23 motors into a Cherry Pi III printer.
Changes from the original are as follows:

• Moved motor inboard 10mm
  • Increased height of part to accommodate motor
  • Extended "foot" further because of increased height
  • Moved tool holes to fit new motor mount locations

    Top Bracket with M5 Bearing Mount

  • Shortened mount path to bring bearing 3mm further inboard
  • Note: the M5 screw can remain the same length, the idler will must be moved.

    Mini V Wheel Rod Carrier

  • Extended belt mount by 3mm to hopefully catch the belt when it's in a new location

    Update 8/14/2014:
    I have successfully built a printer using these files. I can report that the tool access for the motor mounts is a little tight and will likely need to be drilled bigger for your needs. Otherwise, everything works great!

Hi Guys! If you intend to build this Turntable, please wait a few days. I am currently developing a major update. It will be easyer to control, will have more features and you'll need less electronic parts. Best,
Bernhard

This is an instruction to build a arduino based 3D-scanner turntable for small objects. Watch the video at: http://youtu.be/n9UiJGrGvfY You need: 1) An Arduino uno: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/11021 2) A stepper motor: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/9238 3) One EasyDriver stepper motor driver: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/10267? 4) A David Scanner: http://www.david-laserscanner.com/ Building instructions: I) Print both parts an assemble the turntable II) Connect the Arduino with a breadboard to the stepper driver as shown in the picture. More information about programming the stepper dirver: http://danthompsonsblog.blogspot.co.at/search/label/EasydriverTutorials III) Attach a push-button on Arduino Pin 7 IV) upload the firmware to Arduino V) Plug in VI) Have fun!

author: m4rk

description.text:
This is a derivative of "Knob for a 1/4in. Hex Screw by noobcake":
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3596 I had a problem tightening a couple of metric M8 threaded clamps on my old drill press using the stock "7 bump knob" (2nd photo shows original and improved version). They never worked right and after looking at Noobcake's design, thought his would work way better. It did. There are 2 changes to the original design. The knob's hex opening now fits an M8 threaded hex nut and there is a hole through the knob to accommodate the 3" bolt shaft on the clamp.

Print using your favorite SkeinForge settings.  I set INFILL SOLIDITY RATIO to 0.3 in the FILL menu which provided a lot of strength to the star fingers.  You might do some sanding on the back and front with 220A as needed.  The M8 (8mm or 5/16" thread) hex nut should press fit into the opening after you clean out the leftover plastic cobweb.  If you really want a sturdy nut installation, thead the nut on a mating screw held by a pair of pliers over a flame for 10-20 seconds and then press it into the nut recess.  Hold in place until it cools down about 1 minute.

comments.author: remcka

comments.text: piano1
comments.author: changhwac

comments.text: I'm not familiar with the Cura software, (I use Makerware) so I'm afraid I have no idea what is causing your problem. Could it be a metric/imperial issue? The model is 1/24th a full-size piano, so the actual width of the STL model at the keyboard end is 2 1/2 inches (or 6.35 cm.) and the length of the model's case is 3 7/32 inches (or 8.176 cm.)  Sorry I can't be more helpful.
comments.author: Winslow

comments.text: You are dead right Winsolw, it is indeed a metric imperial issue. as per this link http://www.makerbot.com/blog/tag/inches-in-mm/ all I had to do was scale up piano case by 25.4 and now everything fits perfectly. Many thanks for both your help and this wonderful model
comments.author: Winslow

comments.text: I also met some metric issues, so you mean, the piano case should be printed in inches, but others should be in millimeters?

Parts are all printed separately. You will need four stool legs and one of each of the other parts.  Make sure the piano case is lying on its back for printing to avoid overhangs. Final assembly is easy as the parts are designed to slot together in the correct positions. A dab of superglue will hold them permanently in position.

comments.text: I made one on a Prusa i3 Electron from Kit. Made it in translucent filament. Halfway thru the print, I heated a soldering iron I use for melting plastic and paused the print, long enough to flatten some of the infill. Just enough to fit a Blue LED with the two leads coming out slots I made in the piano top edge with a heated razor blade. I also put my friends name between the legs to personal this little lighted piano for placing on the real thing as a gift when passing thru town.

author: Frozengun

description.text: a boat
A holiday decoration using RGB self-changing LEDs.

Use dxf file to laser cut parts in 5mm acrylic. Assembly will require five M3X20mm screws for the star and two M3X16mm screws for the mounts. I used 80grit sandpaper to create the frosted look for the top layer. The LEDs are preprogrammed RGB fading color changers. NOT regular LEDs. Cut perfboard into disc that will fit into center of star with about 2mm of clearance.
Align the LEDs with Anodes on one side and of the board and Cathodes on the other.
Solder the ends together to create a parallel circuit. Power with 3V supply, normally you use a resistor in the circuit but I've found to be unnecessary.
Smiley face earrings. Print 'em, paint 'em, and add earring wires :)
Designed in autodesk 123D design, printed at .2 layer height. Painted with acrylic paints.

Cheap Motorcycle equivalent of dash-cam.

Love GoPro, love the idea and safety of dash-cam. But GoPro is too expensive for me (losing £250 is too much) and GoPro is too big and heavy for me to feel comfortable with it mounted to my crash helmet, so I came up with this. Tip: Once little fingers have been on lens it is a good idea to clean it. Better result video here: https://www.dropbox.com/s/6i4xbzhebb8mh1g/2014_06_25_18_00.mp4 Print PenHold.stl with 0.2mm layer thickness. Camera is currently available on EBay for £3.50, search for "Spy Pen Camera", typical: http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/30fps-Mini-USB-Spy-Pen-DVR-Video-Hidden-Camera-Digital-Camcorder-DVR-up-to-32GB-/271482826360?pt=UK_CCTV&hash=item3f35a32e78
When I bought them they were £10 and I have bought 4 so far (for various people). They come from China or Hong Kong, so expect a wait. There are various different types (mega pixel sizes) and you don't always know which one you are getting (pot luck), but they all seem really good for the price. Wide angle lens is currently available on Ebay for £1.58, search for "magnetic wide angle lens", typical: http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/Magnetic-0-67X-Wide-Angle-Macro-Lens-for-Apple-iPhone-4S-4G-3GS-iPod-touch-K-/170839605159?pt=UK_Mobiles_Accessories_RL&hash=item27c6d57fa7 You will need an MMc, I use 16GB. So, cost is roughly £3.50 + £1.58 + plastic (for printing) + MMc, compares quite well to GoPro for £250. Basically, print it, put it together as shown by the exploded diagrams, use it. This design is perfect for fitting to my ViPER open face crash helmet, this does not mean it will work with yours without editing.
When you get the Spy Pen Cam, unscrew pen bottom (don't need that). Remove pocket clip (don't need that, gets in way of lens). It's still a work in progress, I have tried jelly wide angle lens, didn't like it, this one is better. I have a fish-eye, but I think that will be worse. It could do with changing colour to black etc.
Now modified bracket to angle mount by 5 degrees, road better centred in video.

remixed_from.author: iamjonlawrence
remixed_from.title: Double Precision Y GT2, Printrbot Simple

description.text:
I have modified my previous 300mm No Sag to work with the 1405 Makers Simple. I am a believer of active cooling, so I have included provisions for fans for the extruder motor, hot end, and part. These are completely optional, except the extruder fan which is required for the E3D and Hexagon versions.
This version is compatible with both the 1405 Printrbot stock YZ plate or the included printed plate and can be configured as both single and double precision. The benefit of using the the included printed plate is it separates the bearings and allows you to achieve a greater printing area.
Included are two versions of the front end. The standard one which will work with the Ubis and E3Dv5 hot ends, The "Short" one which will work with the E3Dv6 and Hexagon hot ends. Discussion can be found at: http://www.printrbottalk.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=113&t=7647 2014-06-24: Updated the short version of the front end to use a 30mm fan instead of a 40mm fan for the extruder cooling. The 40mm fan brought the cooling duct down around the heat cartridge (too low). 2014-07-10: Uploaded alternate part fan and mount to work with the Ubis. May not work with the E3D.

No supports are needed.
There are a couple parts with captive nuts where I had to leave some material over the screw hole in order for it to print clean and without supports. The down side, you will have to drill the 1/2mm thick skin over the screw holes on the bearing cap and DoubleYFrontBeltEnd.

comments.text:
I would assume you are missing steps.
First, check to make sure the bearings are aligned by disconnecting the belt and sliding the Y axis back and forth by hand. It should move very freely. If there is a lot of resistance, correct your bearing alignment and make sure everything moves freely.
If everything moves without resistance, and you are still skewing, you may need to increase the current to the Y motor, or slow down your acceleration.
I would recommend a cooling fan on the motor to make sure it does not overheat and warp the plastic it is bolted to.

comments.text: It's worth noting for anyone that is using this mod with the auto-bed leveling, that software can't compensate for a twisted axis. You'll want to take the time to ensure that your ends are tight, square and as true as possible. If they are skewed, then the extruder end will rotate slightly along the Y axis during Y travel. This causes the hotend tip and the bed sensor to be a different Z heights at the front and back of the bed. The symptom that this causes is after a successful bed leveling, the hotend will dive into the bed at one end and be too high at the other. I spent a few days chasing down what I thought was a software bug with the auto bed leveling code, when it was as simple as straightening my axis.

comments.text: What is the difference between single and double precision? I see these on a lot of your mods and was curious.
comments.author: quillford

comments.text: The double precision doubles the number of steps required to move a certain distance.  For example, instead of taking 80 steps/mm the double precision would take 160 steps/mm.  This increases the ability of your motor to move in very small increments.  Makes circles and diagonal lines very smooth.  If all your parts are square, you most likely will not see any difference.
comments.author: quillford

comments.text: Why does it double like that? I decided to reprint my Y axis and did double precision, not thinking that my steps would have to be doubled. I have been trying to think of a reason why it would be double but can't!

comments.text: Ok, going over the bill of materials for single precision, it requires: 1 GT2-20 pulley (isn't this the one that is on the stock y-axis?) and 1 608 bearing (aren't the 624 bearings that come with the 2014 1405 the same size, or at least usable?) I have 406mm rods/new belts ready to go in and hardware, I don't think I need anything else?
comments.author: xdmlaser

comments.text:
You can confirm the number of teeth on the pulley by counting them. I know too simple an answer...
608 bearings measure 8mm ID, 22mm OD, and 7mm wide.
624 bearings measure 4mm ID, 13mm OD, and 5mm wide.
608 bearings are extremely cheap (~$1/ea) and available everywhere in the world. The 624's may work on the YZ plate, but to use the double precision portion you need the 22mm OD. Now you could print up a sleeve to put over the 624 bearings to increase their OD if you were so inclined.

comments.text: Now I know it's called no sag but does it even sag a little? For me if I home it then extend the Y axis it will scratch the build plate when it reaches the end. Any idea on why or how to fix this?
comments.author: CodeRedCardinal

comments.text: In the real world, nothing is perfect.  The Z rods flex, linear bearings have some clearance, and y rods flex, so the further you go up and out the more these factors come into play.  There is also the possibility the Z axis is not perfectly square to the X rods, or the YZ plate is printed out of square. The simple is a good little machine, but there are limits...

comments.text: How do you get your prints to stick to your printbed so well?? I've been having serious trouble with my Simple's prints peeling up off the print bed.
comments.author: TheProfessor

comments.text: I use blue painters tape.  You want the type that has almost a waxy look to it.  I also don't cool until the 5th layer and add a 5mm brimm if I do get curling.  My nozzle is basically touching the tap as it drags across it, so I get high pressure on the first layer.  I don't do anything more than 100% extrusion.  I usually have to pry my prints off now.  Jon's heated bed sounds better, but I'm not going to do that mod until later.
comments.author: TheProfessor

comments.text:
This is a challenge. Personally I never managed to do it without a heated bed. Many others have been successful and I believe the trick is to extrude at the lowest possible temp, and good bed prep.
If you haven't already, check out http://www.printrbottalk.com/http://www.printrbottalk.com/ where there is a very active community and tons of help.
I print on glass with Suave extreme hold hair spray (and heated bed). Ever since the addition of the heated bed my parts are flat every time, no more struggling, and when it cools a small tap and they pop right off.
comments.author: TheProfessor

    Four M3 nuts

author: teneopreto

description.text:
This bed leveling tool fits over the bed stand offs between the heated build plate and the bed allowing the user to manipulate the standoff without a wrench.
This part comes in 6 mm and 7 mm to accommodate the two common standoffs sizes used on the Hadron ORD Bot
The 7 mm wrench is included to complete the leveling kit.

Build all of the parts without support and at the highest infill possible. I like to use 80% infill or higher with a minimum of 2 perimeters. Measure your stand offs and make sure that you build the correct size tools. I have provided both 6mm and 7mm. If you require a different size try scaling the parts.
The Bed Leveling tool is pressed over the top of the stand offs between the bed and the heated build plate. Be sure to press the tool down until it is even with the top of the stand off. The parts are very tight and may need to be pressed on with pliers. Re assemble the heated build plate with the leveling tool now trapped between the plates.
To use the new leveling tool, first loosen the screws that hold the heated build plate Use the included plastic wrench to loosen the lock nuts on the bottom side of the build plate. Use the new printed leveling knob to adjust the corners of the heated bed to t the desired height. Finally hold the adjustment knob while you tighten the lock nut and the screw that holds heated build platform.

comments.text: The bed is a Helios, they are no longer produced to the best of my knowledge The last place I saw them for sale (https://www.panucatt.com/product_p/hbp200.htm) They are very nice heated beds because the thick fiberglass board under the heated traces is very rigid and will not warp like the thinner heated build plates. The build plates are very nice but they are tough to find.

description.text: A Mermaid Model that is made from a bunch of derivatives

Instructions You might need to scale this model to fit your printer, and reasonable scaling should produce good results. You should probably print this with support material enabled, although if you modify the arm angle in blender you might be able to get it to print without support. I removed my support up with a pair of wire cutters and did some smoothing with a nail file and a Rotary Tool. Be careful on the hands as the fingers are rather fragile. I Printed with ABS White plastic Be warned this model is not open scad friendly out of the box; blender is the recommended editing software for this model. This model could use some more refinement and segment scaling and smoothing to look better. Nevertheless, this model was designed based upon the fact that printing acts like a mechanical filter that will remove most of the joint imperfections; However, feel free to clean it up in blender. I like to run my printer slow and steady since my print deck has a tendency to dance around a bit so your configurations will vary. I printed it with the following slicer settings Layers and Perimeters
Layer height .3
Vertical shells 2
Solid layers 4 top and 2 bottom Infill
Fill Density .25
Infill 1
Solid infill every 6
Fill angle 45
Solid infill threshold area 70 Speed
Perimeters 50
Small perimeters 50
Infill 50
Solid infill 50
Top solid infill 50
Support material 60
Bridges 50
Gap fill 40
Travel 60 Filament and Temperature
I was printing with 1.75mm filament with a bed temperature between 95C to 110C and a hot end temperature of 220.

UPDATE: Realized my math was wrong and printed out one of the original files. (wasn't 1/16" gap) So I added a file with 1/16" walls and left the 1/32" wall version.
3/4" Aluminum Square Tube Bushing with 1/16" Walls
3/4" Aluminum Square Tube Bushing with 1/32" Walls

title: Auto-level sensor holder, for printrbot Simple 2014

description.text:
My original version of the probe-sensor holder, distorted badly with heat, see last picture. So I had another go.
This time I decided to strengthen the holder with some metal support. I originally was thinking of using coathanger wire, but a look in my odds and ends draw found a 65mm nail, it's 2.5mm diameter.
This nail sits inside the main body. I have used it for about a week now and whilst it has bent slightly, I believe it will hold up.
With only a week of test time this will stay as a work in progress for now.
This is for the Printrbot Simple 2014 with wooden extruder.
28/05/2015
I never did get Auto-levelling to work CONSISTENTLY, go here to see how I went back to manual levelling.
Bed Levelling/Height adjusting screw/clips
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:850245

It's printed as two halves. You will need a 65mm * 2.5mm nail. My nail was very slightly tapered, and so I had to file it round a bit at the top, this helped clean it up as well. And a couple of M3 bolts, mine are 10mm long.
I think the pictures are self explanatory.
The probe is about 40mm to the left of the extruder.
I use
M212 X0 Y0 Z-1.7
Then my start G-code is
G28 X0 Y0
G28 Z0
G29
So my metal bed is 50mm longer on the X axis to the left.
These settings work for me using bedlevel-v2-pb.hex on
https://github.com/Printrbot/Marlin/releases
Its about 90% effective.
I messed about with X0 to X40 to X-40, it just went haywire.
There are just some things/settings that are vague and unexplained!
Or I am just dense, and cant see it.
I am sure it will be sorted some time, and the probe holder will be useful.
I just enjoy designing, for the sake of it.

comments.text:
https://github.com/Printrbot/Marlin/releases, the Simple-Metal-1403-Firmware.
Had to put my Front Mount Stabiliser and Y-switch reverse, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:379587,
as the home is now at the back, also had to swap some of the motor cables around, not necessarily as specified on that page, but it's fairly obvious if it's going in the wrong direction.. Auto levelling has never worked properly for me. After the sensor has probed the 3 points, I then tuck a 0.2mm wedge under the front left of the print bed and it works fine. In the winter I intend to go to Ramps 1.4, hoping to resolve issues. But the sensor holder in this design has been working and rigid since installed.

The extruder platform and y-axis with endstop have been modified with a place to run a 1/4 x 20 threaded rod with a nut on each end to keep the entire y-axis from wobbling or shaking too much. With taking all the weight away from the rear end the extruder/fan may weight down the front end.
The sandwich middle, middle modified, and middle modified 2 are all part of the same piece that replace all of the original wooden parts of the Y and Z axis. (note: the Z axis adapter here is fit for a connecting nut approx. 1 inch long or you can just use brass)

title: Adapter Ring for Sony A350 Camera to Meade ETX-90 Telescope

description.text:
A adapter ring to hookup up the Sony A350 camera to the ETX-90 Telecope. 
New file: adapter ring from Telescope 35mm diameter to 43mm diameter tubes. (connects the telescope to other adapters).

Print this with a solid fill setting of at least 20%. To use it first attach it (screwing) to the ETX and then lock your camera on the other end. If you leave the wort "TOP" upward it will take pictures in landscape mode.
The ring supports the locking mechanism in the camera so remember to press the release button to unhook the camera.

The Replicator 5 has an enclosed Spool compartment that requires a particular spool fit which cannot be easily formed from plastic pipe.
The Spool here consists of a core as well as sides formed from 4 components each that snap together.
Constructed with OpenSCAD.
[Update 11/14: Spool core is slightly thinner (to run smoothly), properly turned, spool side segments added.]

Print with .3 layers, 30% infill. The object prints with flat bottom, but there is a raft-like ring that can be removed (to make space for the spools side).
The sides of the spool can be made from MDF, or from the printed units. They are attached with small screws (or potentially even just wire) through the holes along the rim.

I redesigned my printable MakerBottable 3x2x1 Rubik's Cube v4 in OpenSCAD, using Tony Buser's pin connection system.  
I just designed this, so I haven't tested it yet.
Update:  I forgot to mention that I created two print plates - one designed for the Thing-O-Matic (marked ToM) and the other for the Replicator (marked Rep1).  They are identical parts, but with the Rep1 they are placed farther apart.

remixed_from.author: fflood
remixed_from.title: Roth Hand (Progressive and Independent Finger Movement)

description.text:
This a variant of the Robohand / Mech-en Hand designs that I've been working on for my daughter who was born with a moderate case of symbrachydactyly in her left hand that left her with only a functional and normal thumb The aim of this design is to create a tendon driven mechanical hand that allows the use of her thumb The design goals for this have been the following:
  • Fingers with 2 joints
  • Fingers offset with respect to one another (not all parallel)
  • No elastics in the design, push-pull actuation
  • Scalable and printable to a very small size along with hardware that allows for this
  • Complete freedom of movement of the wrist - deviation as well as flexion and extension
  • Adaptive grip, allowing the fingers to adapt to the shape of the object in the hand
  • Printable on a typical FDM printer without the need for support structures
    • Its still a work in progress, and the design has come along this far thanks to the amazing internet community called E-Nable. Come join us!! https://plus.google.com/communities/102497715636887179986
    For more information and amazing stories:
    http://enablingthefuture.org
    https://www.facebook.com/enableorganization

Included in the files are the STLs for printing as well as the Solidworks source files. Also included are a couple of assembly animations to show how the hand is put together The idea of this design is to have 2 independent parts (palm and anchor) sown onto a flexible fabric thats comfortable in the capacity of a glove - I havent finished testing this portion yet, so any input and ideas would be more than welcome...... Full Hand.STL has all the files laid out for printing To put the hand together you'll need dowel pins. The pins go through the joints with an interference fit in the holes on the outside and the inside joint has a loose fit around it allowing it to rotate freely There are 2 smaller pins in the intermediate and proximal joints that act as stops preventing the finger from overextending
The fingers have been sized for the following 2 dowel pin sizes
3/32 x 5/8 inch, Qty = 4 per finger
1.5 x 10 mm, Qty = 2 per finger Once the fingers have been assembled, they slide into the palm. Its designed to be really tight, if you use a lubricant, they'll go in with some light tapping, otherwise some light sanding would be required before inserting the fingers Tendon: This hand is designed to use push pull actuation so strings that work with the other Robohand designs wont work here
I've tried a bunch of different cables and I'm the most satisfied at the moment with Nickel Titanium Cables. Theyre incredibly flexible, kink resistant and work very well as push pull cables This company called Aquateko makes fishing leader cables with this material at very reasonable prices and they come in a large range of sizes
http://www.aquateko.com/category_s/21.htm The cable would need to be crimped at one end so it doesnt slip thru the fingers. The fingertips have larger holes to accommodate a crimp Route a length of cable from the fingertip. When it gets to the palm, you'll need to pull the cable thru here, then bend it back again to route through the palm The Anchor is designed to hold an individual anchor per cable and a spring. This is to allow for an adaptive grip and allow wrist motion even after the fingers are closed
The spring sizes that the anchor was designed for are
Free Length: 1.375"
Outer Diameter: 0.187" For the anchor, you can use one of the following 2 solutions E/Z Connectors: Can be found in any hobby store
http://shop.dubro.com/p/heavy-duty-e-z-connector-qty-pkg-2/aircraft_e-z-connectors?pp=12
You dont need the snap washer or the stem at the bottom, route the cable through and tighten the screw at the length you desire The other option is a bolt, nut and washer
Drill a hole in the middle of the bolt shank, just below the head
Route the cable through and clamp down with the nut and washer

It's a 4 in 1 thing!
  • It's a spinning top using a M10 nut as weight.
  • With the hexagon tip you can kick away tiny balls like in one of those roulette game.
  • Write numbers on the nut to make a D6 dice.
  • Use the screw part as "Iron Thumb Wheel" or as balance weight.

You will need a M10 nut, 4 x M3 nuts and a M3 bolt.
Insert the printed screw into the M10 nut and fill the nut traps with the M3 nuts.
Put the one M3 nut between the printed tip and the M10 nut for interlocking. Try different bolt length and lock the nut on different heights with additional M3 nuts to find the balance point.
